pages.text: Energy storage takes space and some heavy weight components. As such, storing large amounts of energy in each tool individually is inefficient and makes them akward to wield.

After constructing the frame as shown here, take it to the $(l:essentials/workbench_and_blueprints)Engineer's Workbench$() to place an $(l:storage/electric_storage)Accumulator$() inside. The Accumulator Backpack acts as a compromise, offering a centralized storage of energy for any powered tools to tap into. $(br)The backpack charges any tools held in main- or offhand as well as any armorpieces you are wearing. $(br)The accumulator can be worn on your back like a piece of chest armor, or you may attach it to most common sets of armor in order to gain the benefit of a power-supply as well as protection.

By attaching a Charging Antenna to the backpack, you can charge its accumulator on the go! Simply walk underneath an $(l:transportation/power_transportation)un-insulated powerline$() to have the antenna connect to it. $(italics)This works best when the powerline is positioned four blocks above the backpack-wearer.

The Induction Charger allows the accumulator backpack to charge all the items in your inventory instead of just those in your hands. Due to not using a direct wired connection however, this charging is much slower.

As its name may suggest, the Miniaturized Tesla Coil is much like its $(l:electric_machines/tesla_coil)larger sister$(), a device that delivers dangerous shocks to nearby targets. It does so in response to the wearer being attacked, thus substituting thorny armor for electicity.
Due to attaching at the top of the backpack, the coil cannot be used at the same time as the Charging Antenna.
